title: Density Gradient Ultracentrifugation for Investigating Endocytic Recycling in Mammalian Cells
procedures:
1. Mammalian cell culture and transfection
Plate 2 x 106 cells in a 100 mm culture dish. Use four dishes for each transfection.
	NOTE: The number of cells required may vary for different cell lines. Optimization may be necessary before proceeding to the isolation step.
The next day, transfect the cells with Lipofectamine according to the manufacturer's instructions.
2. Cell harvest
Discard the culture medium 48 h post-transfection.
Wash the cells with ice-cold PBS (10 mM sodium phosphates, 2.68 mM potassium chloride, 140 mM sodium chloride) twice.
Add 1 mL of ice-cold PBS+ (PBS supplemented with 0.5x protease inhibitor cocktail and 0.5x phosphatase inhibitor cocktail) to each dish.
Collect the cells with a cell scraper and transfer the cell suspension to a 15 mL centrifuge tube.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation using a swing bucket rotor at 400 x g for 5 min.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet gently in 5 mL of homogenization buffer (HB; 250 mM sucrose, 3 mM imidazole at pH 7.4, 1 mM EDTA supplemented with 0.03 mM cycloheximide, 1x protease inhibitor cocktail, and 1x phosphatase inhibitor cocktail).
Collect the cells by centrifugation at 1,300 x g for 10 min.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 1 mL of HB.
Homogenize the cells with a Dounce homogenizer for 15-20 strokes.
	NOTE: Other homogenization methods, for example, passing the sample through a syringe, could be used. The homogenization efficiency could be revealed by observing the homogenate under a phase-contrast microscope.
Transfer the homogenate to a 2 mL centrifugation tube.
	NOTE: Harvest 50 µL of homogenate with 12.5 µL of 5x sample buffer and label it as total lysate.
Add 0.7 mL of HB to the homogenate.
Spin the diluted homogenate at 2,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.

NOTE: The pellet contains nuclei and unbroken cells.
Collect 1.5 mL of the supernatant and repeat step 2.12 once.
Collect 1.4 mL of the supernatant and label it as post-nuclear supernatant (PNS).
3. Density gradient column preparation
Transfer 1.2 mL of PNS to an ultracentrifuge tube.
Add 1 mL of 62% sucrose solution (2.351 M sucrose, 3 mM imidazole at pH 7.4) to the sample and mix well by gentle pipetting.
	NOTE: The resultant solution is a 40.6% sucrose solution.
Add 3.3 mL of 35% sucrose solution (1.177 M sucrose, 3 mM imidazole at pH 7.4) carefully on top of the sample.
Add 2.2 mL of 25% sucrose solution (0.806 M sucrose, 3 mM imidazole at pH 7.4) carefully on top of the 35% sucrose solution.
	NOTE: The refractive index of the 62%, 40.6%, 35%, and 25% sucrose solutions at room temperature are 1.44, 1.40, 1.39, and 1.37, respectively. The refractive indexes of the sucrose solutions could be checked with a refractometer to ensure the precision and consistency of the experiment.
Fill up the ultracentrifugation tube with HB.
	​NOTE: Temporarily store the prepared density gradient column at 4 °C.
4. Fractionation and recovery of recycling endosome-containing fraction
Centrifuge the column at 210,000 x g for 3 h at 4 °C.
Collect 12 fractions (1 mL each) carefully, starting from the top of the gradient.
	NOTE: The recycling endosomes should be found at the interface between 35% and 25% sucrose solutions. The collected fractions can be snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80 °C.
Dilute all the fractions with 1 mL of dilution buffer (3 mM imidazole at pH 7.4, 1 mM EDTA).
Centrifuge the diluted sample at 100,000 x g for 1 h at 4 °C.

Aspirate the supernatant and add 50 µL of 1x sample buffer to harvest the fractions.
Analyze the protein contents in the fractions by western blotting.
